3. API documentation and generated content¶

This page contains general code elements that are common for package documentation.

Table of Contents

  • API documentation and generated content

    • Pandas DataFrame

    • pandas.datetime

    • C++ API

    • JavaScript API

    • Generated Index

    • Optional parameter args

    • Data

3.1. Pandas DataFrame¶

DataFrame([data, index, columns, dtype, copy])

Two-dimensional size-mutable, potentially heterogeneous tabular data structure with labeled axes (rows and columns).

DataFrame.index

The index (row labels) of the DataFrame.

DataFrame.columns

The column labels of the DataFrame.

DataFrame.dtypes

Return the dtypes in the DataFrame.

DataFrame.ftypes

Return the ftypes (indication of sparse/dense and dtype) in DataFrame.

DataFrame.get_dtype_counts()

Return counts of unique dtypes in this object.

DataFrame.get_ftype_counts()

Return counts of unique ftypes in this object.

DataFrame.select_dtypes([include, exclude])

Return a subset of the DataFrame’s columns based on the column dtypes.

DataFrame.values

Return a Numpy representation of the DataFrame.

3.2. pandas.datetime¶

datetime(year, month, day[, hour[, minute[, second[, microsecond[,tzinfo]]]]])

The year, month and day arguments are required. tzinfo may be None, or an instance of a tzinfo subclass. The remaining arguments may be ints.

pandas.datetime.astimezone()¶

tz -> convert to local time in new timezone tz

pandas.datetime.combine()¶

date, time -> datetime with same date and time fields

pandas.datetime.ctime()¶

Return ctime() style string.

pandas.datetime.date()¶

Return date object with same year, month and day.

pandas.datetime.dst()¶

Return self.tzinfo.dst(self).

pandas.datetime.fromisoformat()¶

string -> datetime from datetime.isoformat() output

pandas.datetime.fromordinal()¶

int -> date corresponding to a proleptic Gregorian ordinal.

pandas.datetime.fromtimestamp()¶

timestamp[, tz] -> tz’s local time from POSIX timestamp.

pandas.datetime.isocalendar()¶

Return a 3-tuple containing ISO year, week number, and weekday.

pandas.datetime.isoformat()¶

[sep] -> string in ISO 8601 format, YYYY-MM-DDT[HH[:MM[:SS[.mmm[uuu]]]]][+HH:MM]. sep is used to separate the year from the time, and defaults to ‘T’. timespec specifies what components of the time to include (allowed values are ‘auto’, ‘hours’, ‘minutes’, ‘seconds’, ‘milliseconds’, and ‘microseconds’).

pandas.datetime.isoweekday()¶

Return the day of the week represented by the date. Monday == 1 … Sunday == 7

pandas.datetime.now()¶

Returns new datetime object representing current time local to tz.

tz

Timezone object.

If no tz is specified, uses local timezone.

pandas.datetime.replace()¶

Return datetime with new specified fields.

pandas.datetime.strftime()¶

format -> strftime() style string.

pandas.datetime.strptime()¶

string, format -> new datetime parsed from a string (like time.strptime()).

pandas.datetime.time()¶

Return time object with same time but with tzinfo=None.

pandas.datetime.timestamp()¶

Return POSIX timestamp as float.

pandas.datetime.timetuple()¶

Return time tuple, compatible with time.localtime().

pandas.datetime.timetz()¶

Return time object with same time and tzinfo.

pandas.datetime.today()¶

Current date or datetime: same as self.__class__.fromtimestamp(time.time()).

pandas.datetime.toordinal()¶

Return proleptic Gregorian ordinal. January 1 of year 1 is day 1.

pandas.datetime.tzname()¶

Return self.tzinfo.tzname(self).

pandas.datetime.utcfromtimestamp()¶

Construct a naive UTC datetime from a POSIX timestamp.

pandas.datetime.utcnow()¶

Return a new datetime representing UTC day and time.

pandas.datetime.utcoffset()¶

Return self.tzinfo.utcoffset(self).

pandas.datetime.utctimetuple()¶

Return UTC time tuple, compatible with time.localtime().

pandas.datetime.weekday()¶

Return the day of the week represented by the date. Monday == 0 … Sunday == 6

class std::array¶

3.5. Generated Index¶

Part of the sphinx build process in generate and index file: Index.

3.6. Optional parameter args¶

At this point optional parameters cannot be generated from code. However, some projects will manually do it, like so:

This example comes from django-payments module docs.

class payments.dotpay.DotpayProvider(seller_id, pin[, channel=0[, lock=False], lang='pl'])¶

This backend implements payments using a popular Polish gateway, Dotpay.pl.

Due to API limitations there is no support for transferring purchased items.

Parameters

  • seller_id – Seller ID assigned by Dotpay

  • pin – PIN assigned by Dotpay

  • channel – Default payment channel (consult reference guide)

  • lang – UI language

  • lock – Whether to disable channels other than the default selected above
